Title: Relationship between perceptual style and reactivity to motion
Abstract: The relationship between the perceptual-style dimension of field dependence-independence, as measured by the rod-and-frame test (RFT) and the group Hidden Figures Test, and motion disturbance, as evidenced by a version of the Brief Vestibular Disorientation Test (BVDT) was investigated in 83 naval aviation students. Significant correlations were found between RFT scores and BVDT scores. Field dependence was significantly associated with disturbance by the motion stimulus of the test. Apparent contradictions of the present findings with those involving simulator sickness are discussed. (25 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1975 American Psychological Association.

Title: Are certain air accidents explainable through the difficulties of existence?; Certains accidents aériens expliqués par les difficultés de l'existence?
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Relation between peer perception of leader behavior and instructor-pilot performance
Abstract: Studied the relationships between descriptions by peers of the leader behavior of 141 US Air Force instructor pilots and the performance of these pilots on several dimensions of proficiency. The Supervisory Behavior Description scores for Consideration and Structure were each found to be related to various criterion components and to the composite measure of proficiency, with all the relations positive. A multiple R of .50 was obtained by a combination of Consideration and Structure with the composite criterion. Scores obtained through use of the Supervisory Behavior Description by peers appear predictive of leader performance. Instructor pilots with the highest performance scores were those with high scores on both Consideration and Structure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1975 American Psychological Association.

Title: Drug consumption as a reaction to environmental noise; Tablettenkonsum als Reaktion auf Lärm
Abstract: Noise is considered as a tension inducing agent in the physical environment. Reaction to this stressor is by more internal or more external behavioral responses, depending on experience, resources and personality. Consumption of drugs is considered as an internalized behavioral response. In the surroundings of an international airport, it was found that increasing noise levels were associated with increasing consumption of drugs, and that hypnotic medication showed the strongest association. The association was most marked in female, older, unmarried and lower social class segments of the population, reflecting differing levels of social experience and resources. On the personality level, but not unrelated to these socio-structural factors, assessment of one's own competence and a neurasthenic disposition turned out as factors influencing the consumption of pills as a behavioral response to noise. © 1975 Schweiz. Serum- & Impfinstitut.

Title: Factor Analysis of a New Multi-Dimensional Personality Questionnaire - A Check of the Factor Model in Comparison with Similar Methods.
Abstract: A personality inventory, the Temperament-Structure-Scales (TSS), was developed for the psychological selection of aviation personnel. The inventory includes questions about attitudes, behavior and biographical events. The results are reported and compared with a similar research on the 16 P. -F. -test and on the HSPQ. TSS's psychometric data are discussed.

Title: Joint Committee on Aviation Pathology: III. Medical and psychiatric aspects of accident investigation
Abstract: Biomedical factors account for 80-90% of the 600 aircraft accidents each year. Mechanical failures as causative factors are 10-20%. The biomedical factors of fatalities include use of drugs and alcohol in order to cope with a possible stress, anxiety, or frustration in the aircraft. The important role of personality factors in producing stress reactions requires that stress be defined in terms of transactions between individuals and situations, rather than of either in isolation. When stress reactions are observed, it is assumed that these were brought about by stress conditions, and the accident investigator looks for them in order to understand the reaction which leads to the accident. In the field of fatal accident investigation, where the causes of the event must be sought retrospectively (that is, by looking back and reconstructing the antecedent conditions) the investigator usually assumes that the victim must have encountered severe stress to which the behavior represents a response. Since there are variations in reaction patterns in different individuals under different instances of stress, this issue turns us back to consideration of intervening processes and conditions. An individual's behavior is dependent upon the total effect of all the psychosocial variables that went into the making of this individual's life style.

Title: Variability in the emotional reactions of aviators before flight; VARIABILITE DES REACTIONS EMOTIONNELLES CHEZ LES AVIATEURS AVANT LE VOL
Abstract: In 71 healthy aviators, aged 41.9 ± 5.1 yr, the biological state (response to stimuli, fusion point, ocular rheobase, pulse, blood pressure) is modified in comparison with the resting state. These variations are slightly different in the captains. They seem to be related to psychoemotional stress and aeronautical working conditions.

Title: Territoriality and air space communities; TERRITORIALITE ET COMMUNAUTES AERONAUTIQUES

Title: Medical experience in survival
Abstract: The results of an experiment in survival undertaken by a group of ensigns and officers are recorded. The experiment involved walking through a desert for 3 days, covering a distance of 90 km. Weight, urine samples, and hematocrits were taken before and after the experience. The psychological effects on the men is also recorded. The results obtained demonstrate the effects of the men's exposure to the sun's rays, the loss of weight and signs of hemoconcentration and the changes in character and behavior. Emphasis is placed on the need for training ensigns in the techniques of survival, especially in the desert.

Title: Personality makeup of the American air traffic controller
Abstract: Based on scores from the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire, the personality structure of 11,047 persons working as air traffic controllers, and 9886 persons applying for that job, was examined through factor analytic and analysis of variance techniques. It was concluded that air traffic controllers are superior to the general population in all characteristics of personality essential to performance of their work and, further, that applicants for these positions are even better qualified in certain respects.

Title: Psychological reactions in divers
Source title: Journal of the Royal Naval Medical Service
Abstract: Benson's conclusion that the cause of disorientation was a minor degree of vestibular asymmetry potentiated by a distressed response to break off, endorsed the inference which the authors had drawn from their pilot study, that isolation and sensory deprivation compound the stress in an already stressed subject and make him abnormally vulnerable to self engendered erroneous information. The response to sensory deprivation is closely linked to personality, the ebullient extrovert may find it intolerable, the introvert often seeks it, and there is a good deal of evidence that for every person who seeks refuge in retreat to below what might be reckoned the normal level of stimulus there is another who finds repose only at a much higer level of stimulus, for example in the flashing lights and deafening decibels of a modern discotheque.

Title: Some human factors in the flying physician
Abstract: The paper was prepared with two aims: to transmit the image of the high risk physician in the middle of his journey through time and space, with the hope it may have some prophylactic value in reeducating both the doctors and those who care for them to early danger signals of distress; and to provide the background for future research on decision making and human factors, as a most tentative effort to show significant variables in the 80 to 90% of aircraft accidents attributable to 'pilot error'.

Title: The human factor in aircraft accidents; IL FATTORE UMANO NEGLI INCIDENTI DI VOLO
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Crash victim burns to fly

Title: Additional heart rate - an indicator of psychological activation
Abstract: Heart rate and oxygen consumption of helicopter and transport aircraft pilots were measured. During flight operations, the heart rate accelerated without a corresponding increase in oxygen consumption. This heart rate increase beyond that expected from the oxygen uptake, i.e. additional heart rate, is therefore used as an indicator of psychological activation. This activation did not depend only on the actual task, but also on the experience level of the pilot himself. The levels of heart rate (and blood pressure) recorded indicate taht even routine missions may impose a hazard to pilots with unmanifested or latent heart failure. This obviously calls for frequent workload ECG examinations of flying personnel.

Title: Cardiological aspects of the aging pilot
Abstract: The medical expert of an airline will always consider the licensing of a pilot, and particularly an aging pilot, as the acceptance of a calculated risk, minimized by a large amount of information. So far as the heart and arteries is concerned, this information is of an indirect nature. Further risk reduction will be possible with close cooperation between pilot and doctor, the education of pilots to recognize coronary complaints, a preventive program to improve physical condition, and the reduction of risk factors.

Title: Effect of sonic boom on man and animals (review of main studies carried out in France); ACTION DU BANG SONIQUE SUR L'HOMME ET LES ANIMAUX. REVUE DES PRINCIPAUX TRAVAUX EFFECTUES EN FRANCE
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: The French biological program studied the following points: in man, a study of the effects of sonic booms on the population, using opinion polls; the effects of this stimulus on hearing, equilibrium, sleep and the circulatory system, as well as a study of the reaction of startling stimuli; in animals, a study of the effects of sonic booms on behavior, growth and reproduction in certain species living in herds or in groups (chickens, wild birds, cows, sheep, etc.) and the effects on animal production (especially eggs); in parallel with the studies carried out on man, studies were made of the effects of sonic booms on hearing in guinea pigs, and on endocrine responses in laboratory animals with a view to detecting any adaptation, as well as on cardiovascular reactions in dogs. This article presents a concise report on the principal results obtained during these experiments, which were mostly carried out using the permanent sonic boom generator at the Franco German Institute of Saint Louis and using mobile simulators. The main experimental results obtained in France lead to the conclusion that the discomfort induced by sonic booms is essentially of a psychological nature and that the physiological reactions which they lead to are not liable to have severe consequences for man or animals. Moreover, the economic repercussions on farms and animal production units appear to be nil.

Title: Adjustment and maladjustment among basic flying course trainees - b ADAPTATION ET INADAPTATION EN ECOLE ELEMENTAIRE DE PILOTAGE
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: A medical experience of nearly 3 yr leads the author to conclude that aviation clinical psychology plays an especially important role in the basic flying course A clear statement of its aims and methods is an essential prerequisite, for the purpose was not to introduce additional psychological criteria for selection, which would create a new category of reasons for failures besides medical, disciplinary or technical ones. Moreover the author considers these various categories somewhat artificially contrived, for they often mistake the effects for the causes. The distribution of these various 'causes' for failures may be modified fairly appreciably by a psycho pedagogically directed action. A brief review of the various modes of expressing lack of adjustment to the aviation environment suggests the need for a clear knowledge of some data. For instance, in medically expressed disorders discrimination between psychic and organic causes must be discarded and replaced by a more dynamic psychosomatic concept which will take into account the flying environment per se. Whatever the modes expressing adjustment disorders, their common character is their occurrence in the flying situation which is the source of a specific type of anxiety, flight induced anxiety. So the question arises of the involvement of various defense mechanisms. Briefly, 3 major lines of release from flight induced anxiety can be described: behavioral, 'mentalized' and somatized lines; along each line various defense mechanisms can be detected. On the value and efficiency of these mechanisms rests the subject's adjustment. Besides a technical progression in flying skills, there is an emotional and affective one which, to a high degree, conditions failure or success.

Title: Personality differences between male and female air traffic controller applicants
Abstract: Differences in personality structure between 9,886 male and 217 female applicants for air traffic control positions were examined, using the Sixteen Personality Factor Questionnaire. Data were analyzed through the analysis of variance, and factor analytic techniques. It was shown through both methods that the personality structure of male and female applicants for these positions is much more similar than dissimilar.

Title: Psychophysiologic causes of flight accidents and safety measures in transport aviation (Russian)
Abstract: The paper discusses causes of flight accidents in relation to personality factors in pilots, crew members and ground staff. The psychophysiological mechanism of mistakes in an emergency situation is discussed. Safety measures are suggested.

Title: Stress and the air traffic controller
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: More and more frequently certain physical and psychological states appear indicating a general condition of discomfort among people with the occupation of air traffic controller (ATC). This should alarm responsible staff to take adequate measures in order to ensure the fulfilling of the final aim of ATC, which is the maintenance and expedition of an orderly and safe flow of air traffic. In this paper at first a certain number of phenomena which are occurring at this moment and which indicate that something is wrong, are forwarded. Then a short list of several aspects of the job is presented, which request special attention and care. Finally the results of several discussions about the subject are formulated as a general indication into which direction the study might be developed.

Title: Neuroses in aircrew (Bulgarian)
Abstract: The etiopathogenesis of neurosis was studied in 127 pilots. The significance of personality traits and certain environmental factors is pointed out. Etiologically and clinically, the specificity of flying gives certain special characteristics to the neuroses manifested by lowering the adaptive and compensatory mechanisms in respect to gravitational, hypoxemic, vestibular, postular and other variable factors. The causal factors, in order of significance, are flying fatigue, flying accidents, sudden illness during the flight, etc. A frequent symptom was disturbance of emotional stability, developing various kinds of phobic experiences. Psychoprophylactic measures are recommended.

Title: Psycho social studies in general aviation: II. Personality profile of female pilots
Abstract: A battery of psychological tests were administered to 87 female general aviation pilots. The battery consisted of the Edwards Personality Preference Schedule (EPPS), a modified Early Memories Test, and the General Aviation Psycho Social Inventory (GAPSI). Results indicate that female pilots have a distinctive EPPS personality profile. As compared to norms established for U.S. adults, the EPPS means of female pilots are more similar to those of male adults than female adults. Moreover, the EPPS personality profile of female pilots is more similar to the male general aviation pilot profile than to either the adult female or the adult male norms. Female pilots and male pilots deviate in the same direction from means of the EPPS female norms on 15 of the 16 scales. Thus, female pilots have more personality traits in common with male pilots than they have with women in the U.S. population at large. These findings demonstrate the existence of a 'Pilot's Personality' transcending sex distinctions.

Title: Importance of the psychic factor in the origins of flight accidents in general aviation; LA PLACE DU FACTEUR PSYCHIQUE DANS LES CAUSES DES ACCIDENTS AERIENS EN AVIATION GENERALE

Title: Dynamics, diagnosis and disposition of two cases of skyjacking
Abstract: The paper deals with two individuals diagnostically removed from each other, indicating that dynamically skyjackers cannot be placed over a common denominator. Thus, there does not exist a "Skyjacker Syndrome". Hopefully, air piracy will remain a short-lived episode in the history of aviation. Case No. 1, due to mental illness, was found incompetent to stand trial and was remanded to a federal institution for the mentally ill until reaching competency. Case No. 2 was found competent to stand trial. The jury did not recognize a psychiatric defense during his committing the felony of air piracy. He was convicted and sentenced to 20 years in the penitentiary. © 1974.

Title: Alpha index and the degree of anxiety of pilots (Polish)
Abstract: Pilot anxiety was measured according to J.A. Taylor's Manifest Anxiety Scale in 200 pilots with low and high α indices. An inversely proportional relationship was found between the α index and the degree of anxiety.

Title: Comparison of the job attitudes of personnel in three air traffic control specialties
Abstract: A total of 792 journeyman air traffic controllers from ARTCC, TRACON, and FSS facilities answered a four part questionnaire concerning what they liked and disliked about ATC work, how much they liked or disliked certain specific aspects of ATC work, how they felt about shift work, and their level of job satisfaction. In general, the three ATC specialties showed high agreement in their job related attitudes. They liked most of their job tasks and the challenge of ATC work; they tended to dislike management, their work schedules, and job tasks not directly related to traffic control or flight service. Concerning shift work, it was found that the most negative attitudes were associated with night (2400 to 0800) shifts. Controllers also indicated a preference for rapid turn around shift rotation schedules. Finally, these satisfaction questionnaires indicated that approximately 91% of the controllers surveyed were satisfied with their occupational choice. However, most had other career aspirations for the future. The findings were discussed in terms of the similarity of the controller groups to members of other occupations, and in terms of the significance of the findings for improving controller morale.

Title: The flying teams as a means of organizing psychiatric and social aid in an isolated rural district; LES EQUIPES VOLANTES, MOYEN D'ORGANISER DES SOINS PSYCHIATRIQUES ET COMMUNAUTAIRES DANS UNE REGION RURALE ET ISOLEE
Abstract: Following a brief review of the literature the article describes the deployment of psychiatric teams in isolated, deprived, rural areas. The visiting teams were put into operation according to the principles of community psychiatry and were acting mostly as consultants to the local resources. In a little more than a year, 1608 files were started, 25% of this number being for children. The number of adults requiring hospitalization outside the region was reduced from 170 to 47. Local hospitalizations were also studied, and conditions which resulted in the findings in this paper were examined. The usefulness and value of travelling teams in isolated rural areas is emphasized.

Title: Aircraft as an instrument of self destruction
Abstract: Often the relationship between the pilot and his aircraft is such that the aircraft may be thought of as an extension of the pilot himself during the act of flight. If this pilot accumulates stress in his life with which he can no longer adequately cope, he may engage in self destructive acts, some of these within the context of his flying activities. The competent pilot practices and acquires skills which help him deal with the stress of demanding flight situations. However, if this individual exceeds his piloting capabilities, or is already coping with a high stress level to his maximum capacity, the additional stress of a particular flight may overload the total coping ability. Destruction of self, both psychologically and physically, will then most likely occur. Concepts and constructs of self destructive behavior, stress, coping mechanisms, competence and the myth of invulnerability are defined illustrated and related to the pilot population.

Title: Need satisfaction in the identification of the DOR
Abstract: The purpose of the present study was to determine whether student pilots who voluntarily drop from the program (DORs) and those who successfully complete training enter the flight program with different 'needs', and whether DORs and 'completers' differ in their evaluation of the program's ability to satisfy their needs. The needs that were explored were those of the Maslow hierarchy, including physiological, safety, and security, social, self esteem, and self actualization needs. Eighty seven aviation officer candidates were given a questionnaire designed to measure optimism, relevance, and importance in terms of the five needs described above. They were given the test initially on the third day after entering the program (Time I), and then again after 9 weeks of training (Time II). The results indicate that DORs differ from completers in their evaluation of how well their needs are satisfied. Within the first 9 weeks of training, DORs indicated that meeting their needs was more 'important', though they were less 'satisfied' and optimistic' than completers, particularly with regard to the self actualization need.

Title: Control of environmental noise
Source title: Journal of the Air Pollution Control Association
Abstract: The article reviews the current state of knowledge of noise and how people respond to noise. Sources of community noise are discussed and existing federal legislation pertaining to noise is mentioned. Methods of reducing the noise impact on communities from aircraft, surface transportation, and industrial sites are presented. Interior noise in industry, OSHA noise standards and means of controlling the noise to minimize hearing impairment are emphasized. © 1973 Air & Waste Management Association.

Title: Psychodiagnostic investigations among a group of aircraft pilots; INDAGINI PSICODIAGNOSTICHE SU UN GRUPPO DI PILOTI MILITARI
Abstract: An extensive psychodiagnostic study was carried out with 15 aircraft pilots submitted to Rorschach's test. The results were carefully compared with those pertaining to 15 non military pilots and with 15 civilians having the same characteristics of the pilots as far as sex, age and culture are concerned. The pilots are somewhat more intelligent (intelligence of a theoretical type), spiritually more mature and richer of interior life and affective sociability when compared with the normal average. The very few abnormalities observed and the moderate deficiencies reported by the protocols of examination (consisting essentially of neurotic inhibitory and conflictual marks) do not encroach upon the characteristics of their excellent psychological make up.

Title: Psychophysiologic characteristics of the activity of flight personnel of military transport aircraft during low altitude flights (Russian)
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Personality differences among men in selected Air Force specialties
Abstract: Notes that job placement based on aptitude has provided the human resources necessary to perform the U.S. Air Force mission but has not produced a work force that is satisfied with the duty assignments. A consideration of enlistee personality and interests might refine this job placement system. To determine if personality differences exist among 108 male career officers in selected Air Force specialties, Ss were given the Vocational Preference Inventory (VPI). The specialties were compared further by means of the Environmental Assessment Technique (EAT). Significant differences among the specialties of electronics technician, administrative specialist, inflight refueling operator specialist, and security policeman were found on VPI Realistic, Intellectual, Self-Control, and Status scales. In general, the EAT did not differentiate among the specialties. Implications for counselors of prospective and enlisted airmen are drawn. Further research of this type is recommended to provide the data necessary for more refined and effective job placement in the Air Force. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1973 American Psychological Association.

Title: Prompted mental practice as a flight simulator
Abstract: Conducted a study with 23 U.S. Air Force undergraduate pilots in a T-37 pilot training program. The 13 experimental Ss listened to 4 121/2-min tape recordings that prompted their mental practice of landing the T-37 aircraft. Controls did not receive this practice. All Ss were rated by their instructor pilots on procedures and ability to land the aircraft on the mission that followed the last mental practice session. Experimental Ss' ratings on both procedures and ability to land were significantly higher (p < .05) than the ratings of controls. It is concluded that the use of mental practice may be an effective adjunct to any training program that normally depends on costly actual practice of the skill being learned. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1973 American Psychological Association.

Title: Psychosomatic disturbances in air traffic controllers; LES TROUBLES PSYCHOSOMATIQUES CHEZ LES CONTROLEURS DE LA CIRCULATION AERIENNE
Source title: Archives des Maladies Professionnelles de Medecine du Travail et de Securite Sociale
Abstract: The findings in 192 air traffic controllers are discussed. This group presents a rich symptomatology, in which psychosomatic affections are frequently involved. These affections are classified. In addition to this, the specific work situation of these persons is discussed.

Title: Functions, meaning and examination techniques in aviation ophthalmology; AUFGABEN, BEDEUTUNG UND UNTERSUCHUNGSTECHNIK IN DER LUFTFAHRTOPHTHALMOLOGIE
Abstract: In aviation medicine the ophthalmologist must have good clinical and practical experience, and, in addition to this, interest in ophthalmological psychophysiology. He must be versed in general aviation medicine, and must know the effects of oxygen deficiency (anoxia), of linear variations of pressure and of angular acceleration on the visual system. Knowledge of occupational medicine is also demanded when taking care of the licensees. Also discussed are the techniques for fitness examinations; relevance of developing techniques for examination of visual functions in dynamic conditions with respect to time lapse is pointed out.

Title: Personality factors affecting motivation and selection for flying and continued flight proficiency
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: Specific personality factors influence behavior in the air and flight security. Some are important in determining the drive to become a pilot. Others, such as ageing, interpersonal tensions and other forms of natural tension may practised to dangerous behavior in flight. The interaction of the various personality factors with positive and negative effects on flying capacity are discussed. A special need exists for predicting the situations in which a pilot is likely to fail.

Title: Psycho sociological consequences of aircraft noise
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: Methods aiming at quantification of the effects of aircraft noise in the inhabited areas near the airport are described. The history of the subject matter is briefly critically reviewed, with particular reference to British surveys of 1961 and 1967. Experimental suggestions are made as to the survey planning and data analysis. An attempt is made to explain the lack of correlation between the physical and psychosocial data, by attributing it to the impossibility of obtaining reliable uniform data on human behavior. Another approach is based on consideration of complaints. Complaints against aircraft noise correlate numerically with the number of aircraft movements at the airport. Complaints tend to come however from the articulate, affluent house holders and therefore do not represent a random sample of the population. Aircraft noise interferes primarily with such activities as conversation, sleep and TV watching. Should the annoyance exceed a certain level a legitimate question of possible effects prejudicial to health arises. The difficulties in defining the acceptable day and night noise levels and the political nature of the noise problem are stressed.

Title: Functions of a psychotherapist in aviation medicine; AUFGABEN EINES PSYCHOTHERAPEUTEN IN DER LUFTFAHRTMEDIZIN
Abstract: Expert opinions on fitness are limited to diagnostic measures. Foremost are difficulties in personality diagnosis. Psychotherapeutic consulting hours were mainly frequented by management staff and personnel of the technical range. Treatment was given in form of individual therapy according to Leonhard's conception of an individual treatment of neuroses. In taking care of the operative air safety personnel, examinations by questionnaires of 50 subjects were evaluated. The main complaints were disturbances of falling asleep and sleeping through, followed by fully developed and cumulative symptoms that were indicative of a neurasthenia. Heart troubles and stomach disturbances were found, with 3 shift service and overwork being the sources. It was noted that subjects with more intensive problems and stronger loads were stronger individuals. The psychotherapist functions in assisting in improvement of the work climate, supports justified claims of an improvement in working conditions and undertakes preventive and therapeutic care of patients with considerable problems.

Title: Psychologic and psychopathologic aspects of behavior during airline pilot transition training
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: Methods of retraining airline pilots in the transition from one type of aircraft to another are described. The anxieties produced in training are reported to be similar to those of physiological stress and gravitational stress. The International Air Transport Medical Committee's model transition training scheme is described, and is reported to have effected a reduction in the pilots' liability to symptoms of stress. In this training scheme, the tendency for pilots to contrive, in various ways (use of alcohol or sedatives), to sublimate anxieties in order to lessen the effects of stress is openly discussed, and recommendations are made, medically, to help the subject through periods of tension in the course of his training.

Title: Psychotechnical selection of flight personnel in South Vietnam; LA SELECTION PSYCHOTECHNIQUE DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT AU SUD VIETNAM
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: Before a medical examination, 'pilot cadet' candidates underwent a psychotechnical selection procedure consisting of: 8 mental tests of the 'paper pencil' type : the CAT test (Cattell Intelligence Test), scale reading, auditive memory test, visual memory test, the PA test (Pattern Analysis), reading of coordinates and the MCT test (Mechanical Comprehension Test of Bennett). 6 psychomotor tests using different devices: the Diffused Attention device, the Omega apparatus, the Arsonval chronoscope, the stereometer, the Bourdanel optometric scale and Ishihara's series of pseudo isochromatic plates. 2 personality investigation methods: the Guilford Zimmermann questionnaire and the Heyer Courthial questionnaire. Interesting results: About 99% of the candidates in category A, who passed both the preliminary psychotechnical exam and the final medical test, were accepted as pilots after one year's training whereas, for category B, only 25% passed the final pilot's examination. To sum up, for the proper selection of pilot applicants: It is advisable to give 'pilot cadet' applicants a preliminary psychotechnical test before they sit for the final medical examination. It is necessary to 'standardize' universally the psychotechnic examination methods and adopt the 'same marking' in different categories A, B, C, and D. The choice of successful candidates in category A alone, or the two categories A and B, would depend on each country's actual requirements at the time of recruitment. In order not to waste time, it is a good thing not to make candidates sit for 'duplicata tests' which may be held during both the psychotechnical examination and the medical examination such as the measuring of visual acuity, in depth discrimination and the determining of congenital dyschromatopsia.

Title: Psycho therapy of flight personnel; PSYCHOTHERAPIE DES MEMBRES DU PERSONNEL NAVIGANT
Source title: Revue de Medecine Aeronautique et Spatiale
Abstract: The psycho therapy of flight personnel must take into account the particulars of their personalities and the requirements of their professional lives. The results of psycho therapeutic cures carried out over a period of 4 yr allow three categories to be distinguished in this type of treatment: 1) Long cures which generally involve cases almost no different from those found in other professions, para psychotic and neurotic syndromes, the profound etiology of which can be traced to disturbances in the psycho affective development during childhood. Here the incidence of professional factors is usually rather low. 2) Short cures, which last from 2 to 6 mth, corresponding to psycho social maladjustment crises provoked either by professional difficulties or by disturbances in the subject's private life. They usually evolve towards readjustment, but the earlier level of adjustment cannot always be reached. 3) Lightning cures, which require only a few appointments, often correspond to a sharp maladjustment crisis that may be either psycho social (often with a paranoic aspect) or professional (in the right sense of the word), the subject reaching the limits of his resistance to the stresses connected with his profession. Clinical examples show the advantage of psycho therapeutic methods in the various syndromes of the psycho pathology of flight personnel.

Title: Introduction to the study of the psychologic and psychopathologic aspects of safety in aviation; INTRODUCTION A L'ETUDE DES ASPECTS PSYCHOLOGIQUES ET PSYCHOPATHOLOGIQUES DE LA SECURITE AERIENNE

Title: Experimental evaluation of annoyance and nuisance related to sleep disturbances by aircraft and traffic noises; EVALUATION EXPERIMENTALE DE LA GENE ET DE LA NUISANCE DES PERTURBATIONS DU SOMMEIL PAR DIVERS BRUITS DE CIRCULATION AUTOMOBILE ET AERIENNE
Abstract: The influence, due to the characteristics of the noise, on the noise exposed people is considered. The advantages and inconveniences of studies done in the laboratory or in the home are discussed. The necessity of defining objective annoyance and health damage criteria in order to assess acceptable noise limits for housing and town planning is stressed.

Title: Innovations in training: The New Aviation Scientist--Psychologist and Engineer
Abstract: Notes that meaningful research in applied experimental psychology is often conducted as an interdisciplinary effort. This approach is especially prevalent in aviation because particular consideration must be given to human capabilities and limitations in the aircraft system design process. This article describes the Aviation Research Laboratory at the Institute of Aviation of the University of Illinois, which provides a unique environment for graduate training in aviation research. The program is designed to train aviation scientists by providing experience in the analysis and experimental investigation of real man-machine system problems giving joint consideration to behavioral, environmental, and engineering design variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1972 American Psychological Association.

Title: Job satisfaction and job-related health disturbances among air traffic controllers; Arbeitspsychologische Studien über Arbeitszufriedenheit und berufsbezogene Gesundheitsstörungen bei Fluglotsen
Abstract: An inventory study was performed using as subjects 517 (80.3%) of the German air traffic controllers of all German civilian air-ports except Berlin and Saarbrücken. The inventory included 106 questions about job situation, job satisfaction and the subjective health status. The controllers completed the inventories in groups of 20 under the supervision of the test leader. Is was found that the interest of the controllers in their work was particulary high but job satisfaction was particularly low if remarks about individual aspects of the job situation were accepted as a criterium. Reasons for low job satisfaction were: Lack of opportunity for professional advancement, general working conditions, lack of appreciation by the administration, payment and job load. The lack of job satisfaction was very closely related to health disturbances attributed to job situation; age and length of service were also involved. There is a discussion on whether lack of job satisfaction can cause or aggravate job-related health disturbances. © 1972 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Effects of instructions on measures of state and trait anxiety in flight students
Abstract: Administered the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory twice to 134 flight students during their routine entrance aviation physical examination. Ss were lower in trait anxiety and higher in state anxiety than a group of 253 previously tested male college students. However, with an induced anxiety act, both state and trait anxiety scores were significantly lower than the scores obtained during the initial administration of the test. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1972 American Psychological Association.

Title: Psychosocial reconstruction inventory: a postdictal instrument in aircraft accident investigation.
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Aviation and the environment in the 1970s
Abstract: WILLIAM LITTLEWOOD, a Maryland man, will always be remembered as one of that small band of American pioneers in air transport who raised this great industry so successfully into the skies. It is a great privilege for me, an Englishman, to pay tribute to an outstanding American "Aviation Man." Bill Littlewood's dedication to the cause of aviation, his practical approach to aircraft engineering, his integrity, and his warm personality won for him the deep regard of a wide circle of friends on both sides of the Atlantic. As one of the originators of that classic airplane, the DC-3, in company with the great C. R. Smith, and as the man who introduced that airplane and its successors into airline service, Littlewood's name will always live in the annals of our business. Into his 69 years-between his birth in New York City on October 21, 1898, and his death at Martingham St. Michael's, Talbot County, Maryland, on December 5, 1967-Bill Littlewood packed three things we can all envy. First, he achieved distinction in his profession, in his work for American Airlines. Second, there was infused in him-and in Dorothy, his wife-a love of land and sea, especially of the Eastern Shore of Maryland and the waters of Chesapeake Bay. And, third, he and Dorothy together formed a devotion for their alma mater, Cornell University, and all that it stands for-Cornell where Ted Wright was vice-president of research.

Title: SELECTIVE ATTENTION AND PERFORMANCE IN DANGEROUS ENVIRONMENTS
Abstract: Evidence on human performance in dangerous environments is reviewed and suggests that danger reduces efficiency, except in the case of experienced subjects. Perceptual narrowing is shown to be one source of decrement. It is suggested that danger increases the subject's arousal level which influences performance by producing a narrowing of attention. The nature of the performance decrement and of adaptation to danger are discussed in this context. 1972 The British Psychological Society

Title: Disaster alert and the community mental health center
Abstract: Hospitals must be prepared for disasters of indeterminate magnitude in order to fulfill their community function. The protocol for organization of services should be brief, explicit, and define who is in charge of duty assignments. Psychiatrists are uniquely prepared to handle telephone calls from distraught relatives. This paper illustrates that psychiatric staff members of the community mental health center are uniquely prepared to function in the coordinated work of a medical disaster team. © 1971 Behavioral Publications, Inc.

Title: Western European Association for Aviation Psychology,. Cambridge, UK, 21-24 September 1971
Abstract: [No abstract available]

Title: Two Linear Rate-Field Displays
Abstract: An airspeed display and a lateral displacement (runway) display, arranged vertically and horizontally, respectively, were concurrently tracked by relatively inexperienced pilots using a joy stick. On each display the primary indicator was a small band which moved lengthwise. A moiré-pattern rate field (RF) moved alongside and with the primary. Each of four experimental conditions included both primary indicators and (a) no rate fields, (b) the airspeed rate field only, (c) the runway rate field only, or (d) both rate fields. Response measures for each display included (a) latency of initial response, (b) control reversals, and (c) root-mean-square (RMS) tracking error. Rate fields decreased RMS error for the runway display. Latency was briefer, but more reversals occurred on the airspeed display than on the runway display. Rate fields apparently serve an attention gathering function, but this cannot be fully investigated until optimum direction-of-motion relations are determined. © 1971, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Laboratory vs. Field Experimentation in Human Factors—An Evaluation of an Experimental Self-Service Airline Ticket Vendor
Abstract: Human response times in the experimental Automatic Ticket Vendor (ATV) system were studied first in a laboratory test with simulated operation of some parts of the system and then in a field test at the O'Hare airport in Chicago. Results for human response times were comparable in the two tests, but the field test answered other questions about consumer behavior and subjective reactions that could not be studied in the laboratory. This paper compares the test conditions and results and discusses the relative advantages of the two methods of testing for various purposes. © 1971, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. All rights reserved.

Title: The Kennedy airport snown: An inquiry into intergroup phenomena
Abstract: Disaster may serve as a paradigm for examining the complex interplay of many of the factors that influence human behavior. Within the context of the disaster, the interaction of such factors as individual psychodynamics, small group processes, and intergroup dynamics can be examined.1 This paper deals with an existential and theoretical account of a particular disaster, the Kennedy Airport Snow-In of February, 1969, which may in some way illustrate behavioral phenomena common to events of this type. The empirical data derive from one of the authors, who was an affected passenger (C.A.H.).2 The gathering of data of a non personal nature, the integration of the collected information, and the conclusions drawn about intergroup phenomena presume a distance from the initial confusion. © 1971 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Color Coding for Information Location
Abstract: Visual search performance was investigated as a function of color-coded and uncoded information location, number of categories coded, number of objects per category, and background clutter. Thirty-three subjects searched 12 areas of modified sectional aeronautical charts for a total of 48 checkpoints. Identification of checkpoints was established with labels plus geographical context information. Color served as a partially redundant code for information location. In general, the findings indicate that color coding for information location is most effective when: (1) many categories of information can or must be coded, (2) colors highly discriminable in peripheral vision are used, and (3) the number of objects per category is kept reasonably small. © 1971, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. Title: Personality of nickel-cadmium batteries
Abstract: Nickel-cadmium batteries fill a great need in the aircraft industry today. This battery is far superior to its predecessor, the lead-acid battery, in its ability to provide power for larger electrical loads and/or loads sustained for long periods. Yet, aircraft operators have experienced many unexpected problems with this battery. These problems can be greatly reduced, if not eliminated, through a better understanding by the design engineer of the battery's construction, abilities, and limitations. Further improvements in performance can be accomplished by the aircraft operator through constant and proper maintenance.

Title: Effect of threat and uncertainty on mastery of stress
Abstract: Parallel forms of a word association test containing words scaled along a dimension of increasing relevance to parachuting were administered to 20 experienced parachutist at 2-wk intervals. 10 Ss were given the 2nd test under experimental conditions of threat and uncertainty. It was found that during regular testing conditions Ss produced inverted V-shaped gradients, i.e., stronger GSRs and longer RTs to low-intensity cues and high-intensity cues. This replicated an earlier finding with experienced parachutists. When tested under conditions of threat and uncertainty, Ss showed a reversal in their response patterns, i.e., monotonic gradients of GSR and RT to the same stimulus dimension. Monotonic gradients are consistently found for novice jumpers. It was concluded that the process responsible for the backward shift was a function of experience are reversible. Title: Response speed and accuracy during anticipatory stress
Abstract: Response speed and accuracy of 48 general aviation pilots were determined under condition of anticipatory physical threat stress (APTS). Variables included unpleasantness of the event (electrical shock), proximity of the event, and relationship of Ss’ performance to the occurrence of the event. The data support inclusion of these variables in Wherry’s model of APTS. Ss who believed they could avoid the shock by an adequate performance were able to maintain or improve that performance while the performance of Ss who perceived the shock as inevitable was deteriorating. Two possible modifications of the APTS model were discussed: (1) weighting APTS determiners according to their effectiveness in generating anticipatory stress, (2) recognizing the interaction of the APTS variables with S’s personality structure. © 1969 Journal Publishing Affiliates.

Title: The luminous transmission factor of sunglasses
Abstract: The literature relating to the luminous transmission factor of sunglasses is reviewed. Glare, brightness discrimination, night vision sensitivity, visual acuity, reaction time and psychological aspects arc considered, and recommendations are made that sunglass lenses should, in general, have a light transmission within the range 10% to 25%. There appears to be little need for sunglass lenses with transmissions outside this range, even for color-defectives or for persons in occupations such as aviation. © 1969 American Academy of Optometry.

Title: Hypnotic recall of aircrash cause
Source title: International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Hypnosis
Abstract: Hypnotic techniques can be used to help a patient recall suppressed material which implicates him in a devastating disaster. The cause of an air crash was found after 2 short. hypnosis sessions, where other orthodox methods used over a period of 2 years had failed. The method can be used in all cases of amnesia. The patient is made to hallucinate a threatening situation, and his hallucination gives a clue to the basic problem. He is then made to hallucinate a pleasant scene, which gives an indication of the method he uses to escape from the problem. This is repeated at the second session for confirmation. If the patient does not bring up the required material by free association under hypnosis, a dissociation of the personality is induced in which the observing ego watches what the experiencing ego is doing to cause the accident. The results demonstrate that in this case, at least, hypnotic techniques were more successful than sodium amytal interviews, free association, psychiatric interviews, physical and emotional isolation, pressure by authorities, and kindness of friends. Reference is made to the problems involved when the interests of the patient are in conflict with public safety. © 1969, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Mean annoyance ratings of the subjects exposed to several acoustic stimuli varied considerably despite the fact that the stimuli levels in the test room were held constant at 82 db (sound pressure). Title: Improving Time-Sharing Performance of Pilots Through Training
Abstract: Even with special display devices in gestation, a pilot must satisfy his complete visual information needs by “time-sharing” between the intra- and extra-cockpit data sources. A sample of sixty military attack pilots, selected with the variable of flying experience in view, was divided into control and trainee groups. Using simple, generalized but adaptive simulation devices, the trainee group was trained over an eight-week period in display reading and in hazard detection. A comparison of the trainee group with the control group in a highly specific and complex simulated flying task, showed that hazard detection (such as collision) was improved significantly without in any way compromising other flying tasks. © 1968, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. Title: Steepness of approach and avoidance gradient in humans as a function of experience: Theory and experiment
Abstract: 33 experienced and 33 novice parachutists rated their approach and avoidance feelings at different points in time preceding and following a parachute jump. For the novices self-rated avoidance increased up to a point shortly before the jump, and then decreased. For the experienced Ss self-rated avoidance increased up to the morning of the jump, decreased to the jump, and increased after the jump. It was concluded that with experience the point of greatest anxiety is displaced backward in time. To account for this phenomenon, a miniature theory was presented which assumed that with continuous exposure to threat, 2 developments take place, a heightening of the gradient of anxiety and the development of a gradient of inhibition of anxiety, the latter having the steeper slope. Title: The analysis of job performance by multi-dimensional scaling techniques
Abstract: The application of multidimensional scaling methods to the analysis of job performance was explored. Men experienced in the job of Naval aviation electronics technician designated 18 tasks as constituting that job at the entry levels. The work performed by aviation electronics technicians at the job entry levels was perceived by supervisors as involving 4 basic dimensions. Title: Effect of Injury Information on Damage Estimates
Abstract: Aircraft accident research has revealed a relationship between injury to the occupants and damage to the aircraft structure. The present study explores the possibility that judgments of damage are affected by knowledge of injury. Thirty-six male subjects estimated aircraft damage from 36 photographs of aircraft accidents. In connection with each photograph the subjects were provided with fictitious injury (as well as other) information. Accident photographs, subjects and injury levels were appropriately counterbalanced. The major hypothesis was supported. Accident-involved aircraft were given higher damage ratings when the photographs were presented with higher injury levels than when the same photographs were presented with lower injury levels. Suggestions are made for overcoming this bias which exists in the laboratory and which may exist in the field. © 1964, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Visual Experiments Related to Night Carrier Landing
Abstract: There is a substantially higher incidence of carrier landing accidents at night than during the day. Disasterously low final approaches, a major source of night landing accidents, have been attributed to a visual illusion involving overestimation of altitude. In order to evaluate visual performance in related tasks, subjective judgements of the altitude of a luminous horizontal bar relative to eye level were obtained in total darkness and in the presence of a peripheral artificial horizon. Errors as large as 1° visual angle, corresponding to 8 ft at a range of 500 ft from touchdown, occur frequently, indicating the inadequacy of direct visual contact unaided by artificial display devices. The dramatic reduction in variability resulting from the presence of the artificial horizon demonstrates the importance of a visual frame of reference or structure. © 1964, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Schematic Simulation: A Technique for the Design and Development of a Complex System
Abstract: Schematic simulation is the name of a method for studying system specifications and explicating implications of the specifications for subsystem design. The method was developed in response to the expressed need of the designers of a Terminal Air Traffic Control (TATC) laboratory system. The method provides a model of the projected system and a procedure by which the designers can view system operations from the standpoint of the eventual operators. An illustration is given of how schematic simulation was used. © 1964, Human Factors and Ergonomics Society. All rights reserved.

Title: Aircraft conspicuity and flight attitude information provided by exterior paint patterns
Abstract: Experiments were conducted to determine the relative conspicuity of aircraft exterior paint patterns, and to investigate whether such paint patterns aided pilots in determining the attitude of the aircraft. The conspicuity studies, using paired comparisons of model airplanes, gave evidence that: (a) amount of red-orange fluorescent paint coverage is positively correlated with conspicuity; (b) high brightness paints should be placed on the upper surfaces of the aircraft and low brightness paints on the lower portions; (c) maximizing brightness contrasts between different parts of the aircraft surfaces does not enhance conspicuity; (d) flight attitudes, backgrounds, lighting conditions, and differences in Ss did not affect conspicuity significantly. The attitude studies in which pilots matched the model airplanes in some 1 of 15 attitudes, with 1 of 15 models mounted on a small display, indicated that the paint patterns used did not aid the pilots in making judgments of aircraft attitude. Differences in backgrounds and lighting conditions did not greatly affect Ss' ability to determine attitude. Title: Middle Category Response: Reliability and Relationship to Personality and Intelligence Variables
Abstract: Guilford-Martin tests of factors GAMIN, STDCR, and OAgCo had been administered to 344 entering Naval Aviation Cadets. Four weeks later, the Bernreuter questionnaire was administered to 277 of these subjects. Results indicated: (i) The distributions of “?” scores were positively skewed, the shape approximating the J-curve. (2) The reliability for Bernreuter “?” scores was estimated as 64, for a single Guilford-Martin test as 72, for the sum from three Guilford-Martin inventories in the eighties. (3) Question-mark scores were independent of ACE scores and educational level within the restricted range studied. (4) Bernreuter and Guilford-Martin “?” scores correlated significantly, and about equally, with ten Guilford-Martin traits: GAMIN, OAgCo, and TR of Test STDCR. Subjects with many “?” responses tended to rate themselves toward the less socially approved direction on these ten traits. However, the significant correlations reported between “?” scores and personality trait scores appear to be artifacts of the scoring procedure used in Guilford-Martin inventories for the “?” response. It was concluded that independent measures of personality are needed as correlates of “?” responses in order to understand their meaning. © 1955, Sage Publications. All rights reserved.

Title: Factors in the design of clock dials which affect speed and accuracy of reading in the 2400-hour system

Title: The use of psychological techniques in measuring and critically analyzing Navigators' flight performance
Abstract: Under controlled flight conditions, the distance between a navigator's report of position and his actual position is a criterion of success in dead reckoning navigation. Students' logs were evaluated for five separate missions by comparing the students' entries with standards determined by experts. The reliability of this technique is indicated by the fact that mission to mission inter-correlations of error scores were low, while the intercorrelations between legs of the same mission were moderately high. The intercorrelations between the error scores for the different navigation variables were computed and analyzed by using both factor analysis and multiple regression techniques. Both analyses indicated that a major portion of all dead reckoning error could be attributed to errors made in determining magnetic deviation. As a result of these analyses, recommendations were made for changing the instruction in dead reckoning and alterations in the equipment used were suggested. © 1947 Psychometric Society.

Title: The factorial composition of two tests of comprehension in reading
Abstract: A factorial analysis was carried out on the scores made by high school boys and aviation cadets on a 14-test Judgment and Reasoning Battery and other measures of comprehension in reading. Two of the components, Word-Knowledge and Reasoning-in-Reading, were intensively investigated. It was found that the type of reasoning which is important in reading is not of a sort which can be measured in the usual reasoning tests, such as those of syllogistic reasoning, figure analysis, mechanical judgment, or arithmetical problems. This fact argues against the existence of a general reasoning ability. Since perceptual facility proved to be relatively unimportant in determining certain essential elements in reading, the author concludes that instruments such as the Metron-O-Scope and Ophthalmograph cannot aid a pupil's comprehension enough to warrant the expense and trouble of using them. The present study does not touch on the aid they may give a student for increasing his speed of reading. Title: The learning curve for flying an airplane
Abstract: "1. The objective analysis of airplane control movements can be used to show progress in the development of flying skill. 2. By means of the pilot-response recorder and the graphometer, the psychologist can tell which controls the pilot is manipulating incorrectly, in which direction his errors occur, and how great they are. 3. The weather-control technique seems to be adequate to cancel out variations in flying conditions. 4. Learning curves for various maneuvers in flying are essentially the same as those obtained in the development of other skills. 5. There is no evidence of plateaus in the curves of learning to fly, as plotted from the present data." (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1946 American Psychological Association.

Title: The Purdue Mechanical Adaptability Test
Abstract: "Forms R and S of The Purdue Mechanical Adaptability Test were administered to 1,015 industrial applicants or employees already on the job in eleven manufacturing plants. The 'Kelley technique' as described by Lawshe was used for estimating the validity of test items. A revision based on internal and external criteria resulted in Form A of the test for men and boys . . . The item analysis procedures succeeded to a large degree in accomplishing the objective of formulating a test that is relatively unrelated to intelligence as measured by various standard intelligence tests." It is reported as being useful in discovering men and boys who are likely to succeed on jobs of a mechanical nature. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1946 American Psychological Association.

Title: The effects of carbon monoxide on three types of performance at simulated altitudes of 10,000 and 15,000 feet
Abstract: "1. Measurements of the critical frequency threshold, body sway, and the red visual field were made on Ss before, during, and after low pressure chamber runs. Twenty Ss with 12 to 22 percent blood COHb took part in runs at 15,500 feet, and six Ss with 5 to 10 percent COHb were tested at 10,000 feet. Control runs were made at the same altitudes with the same Ss. 2. There was significant impairment of performance at altitude, both under conditions of anoxia alone and anoxia after exposure to CO, as compared with performance at sea level. 3. There was no statistically significant difference between the mean scores of the tests during anoxia and during anoxia following the administration of CO . . ... 4. Individual responses were variable and without correlation with the percentage of increment or of total COHb in the blood." (See also 20: 2302.) Title: The Aviation Psychology Program of the Army Air Forces
Abstract: This is the first of a series describing the Aviation Psychology Program. It deals with the general organization and historical development up to October 1943, giving the locations of centers and personnel and a description of the testing program and schedule. The tests fall into these types: (1) intelligence, judgment, and proficiency, (2) alertness, observation, and speed of perception, and (3) visual-motor co-ordination. Three scores are the result of the classification testing: pilot aptitude, bombardier aptitude, and navigator aptitude. Training is prescribed on the basis of these classification procedures. The research may be divided into the following: analysis of duties and functions, modification or invention of test procedures, refinement and improvement of tests, validation of tests, and determination of efficient test batteries. As the result of this program, constant revision can occur in the technological program. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1943 American Psychological Association.

Title: Utilization of psychologists in the United States Navy
Abstract: Utilization of psychologists by the Navy falls under 3 heads: (1) construction, administration, and interpretation of tests; (2) interviewing, ranging from employment to clinical; (3) special services, covering a wide variety of tasks requiring psychological skills. Psychologists have been commissioned in 4 categories with various rank titles. Most of the article describes the duties of the H-V(S) [Hospital-Volunteer Reserve (Special Service)], which aids in the selection of aviation cadets. At the induction centers, the H-V(S) administers tests, participates in a program of perceptual training, and is available for consultation with instructor and student as psychological problems arise later. At the air stations, the H-V(S) assists in assigning cadets to various types of operation, serves with the indoctrination of personnel in the low pressure chamber, aids in the formulation of exams, and participates in research. Title: Aviation
Abstract: Although the psychology of aviation comprises the selection, training, and maintenance of personnel (pilot, crew, and ground staff) and the care and education of passengers, the main body of the literature has dealt almost entirely with (1) physiological and psychological effects (immediate and cumulative) of flight and the flying environment, and (2) the selection of pilots. This review and bibliography of 92 items excludes the recent work under the auspices of the Committee on Selection and Training of Aircraft Pilots of the National Research Council and some 534 less important references which will be published later. Title: Military psychology
Abstract: This is a selected bibliography of psychological publications relevant to war and military endeavor prepared at the request of the Emergency Committee in Psychology appointed by the Division of Anthropology and Psychology of the National Research Council. There are 14 sections by 27 collaborators: army transport personnel, aviation, classification of military personnel, effects of certain drugs on mental and motor efficiency, fatigue, German military psychology, morale, motivation and learning in relation to the national emergency, perception, propaganda technique and public opinion, psychological causes of war, rehabilitation, war neuroses, and the Gasiorowski bibliography of military psychology. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2006 APA, all rights reserved). © 1941 American Psychological Association.

Title: Student attitudes and vocational choices
Source title: Journal of Abnormal and Social Psychology
Abstract: Students who have chosen as their vocation banking, dentistry, music, and government service are more conservative, whereas more liberal attitudes are found among those planning on journalism, social work, law, and agriculture. Students indicating no vocational choice are slightly below the median on each of the scales used. The most religious attitudes are found among students who have chosen the ministry, home-making, medicine, music, and teaching. The less religious attitudes are found among those choosing aviation, journalism, law, and commerce. Students choosing the ministry are most favorable toward the institution attended. Student vocational choice seems to be more closely related to social, moral, and religious attitudes than is the year in college. Title: Duralumin all-metal airplane construction
Abstract: PSYCHOLOGY of the public, as well as engineering structure and aerodynamics, is involved in commercial aviation. The public has confidence in metal. With quantity production in view, the author and his associates considered costs of production as related to quantity and also costs of maintenance at airports and in the field, and chose metal as the material of construction. Structural members are fashioned from sheet duralumin rather than from tubes and a type of construction was evolved that can be made with the minimum investment in tools, that is cheap to put together and that can be repaired with the smallest amount of equipment and labor. For compression loads, duralumin has a great deal more strength for a given weight than has steel. It cannot be used, however, for compression members in combination with steel in tension members because of the difference in coefficient of expansion. Advantage is taken of the rigidity of corrugated duralumin sheets to use them as wing covering in a way to form part of the structure and prevent torsion. Strength of metal of a given analysis and heat-treatment can be determined within 5 per cent, and all duplicate members made of the same metal have equal strength. This is not true of wood and of wooden members. Parts of a damaged metal airplane can be repaired readily with metal of the same thickness, quality and cross-section and the airplane made as good as when new. Built-up sections of metal riveted together give warning of coming failure, whereas wood and tubular members do not. The exterior of a duralumin airplane needs no painting or other protection against corrosion. The sheets used in the author's airplanes are polished before fabricating and are given no other finish.

Title: Monocular and binocular judgment of distance
Abstract: The studies here reported and summarized in Fig. 1 seem to show that binocular parallax is the essential factor in depth perception, and hence that for accurate judgment good binocular vision is necessary. The standard heretofore required might properly be raised. These studies were made in the Department of Aviation, Psychology Medical Research Laboratory and School for Flight Surgeons, Mitchell Field, L. I., N. Y. © 1922.

Title: Psychological Research in Aviation in Italy, France, England, and the American Expeditionary Forces
Abstract: Psychology well needs to thank its stars that the World War came, and that it brought demands, situations, problems, apparatus, contacts of national and international scope, herds of men gathered together, and dynamic interest in technical and practical pursuits of a psychological nature. Reference is here being made most specifically to the reaction-time experiment for one, salvaged by the workers on aviation problems. And new experiments with new techniques were fashioned and new combinations of old techniques were instituted. What experiments were designed and performed to meet the requirements attending the classification of aviators and prospective aviators in Italy, France, England, and this country during the war are admirably and extensively described by Dockeray and Isaacs in this article, the summary being an excellent review of the foreign and domestic literature on the subject. Many and exceedingly interesting results of the experiments, most of them obtained from numerous subjects, are cited, but they are too numerous and too well organized in the writers' summary to enumerate here. Two important results were the following: (1) Practically all of the best pursuit pilots belonged to the sensory reaction-time type, and exhibited a keen perception of the position of the body, low visual reaction-times, low choice reaction-times, and a low average deviation in reaction-time. Resistance to influences of emotional stimuli was not always present or necessary, some of the best pilots being quite susceptible to emotional conditions. (2) Practically all of the best slow machine, bombing, aviators were motors in reaction-time; and Caproni pilots exhibited resistance to emotional stimuli. From Psych Bulletin 18:06:00361. Title: Psychology in relation to the war
Abstract: Twelve committees for helping in the war effort were authorized by the APA. These committees were involved in collecting and making available relevant psychological literature, examination of recruits, motivating the troops, treatment and re-education of incapacitated troops. A committee of seven psychologists tested out various methods during May-June 1917. Five groups of three men each were organized for examining recruits in four different military establishments, with the purpose of classifying recruits as mentally "inferior", "average", or "superior". The work justified itself on the practical counts of acting as aids in selection, elimination, promotion and assignment of men. The other committees also proved themselves to be of great utility in development of scales, selection of aviation cadets, identification of special abilities and reeducation.
